citeinfo.title: Evidence for nonuniform permafrost degradation after fire in boreal landscapes

pubinfo.publish: Journal of Geophysical Research - Earth Surface

descript.abstract: Fire can be a significant driver of permafrost change in boreal landscapes, altering the availability of soil carbon and nutrients that have important implications for future climate and ecological succession. However, not all landscapes are equally susceptible to fire-induced change. As fire frequency is expected to increase in the high latitudes, methods to understand the vulnerability and resilience of different landscapes to permafrost degradation are needed. Geophysical and other field observations reveal details of both near-surface (<1 m) and deeper (>1 m) impacts of fire on permafrost along 11 transects that span burned-unburned boundaries in different landscape settings within interior Alaska. Data collected along the 11 transect locations include: electrical resistivity tomography (ERT), downhole nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), active layer thickness (ALT), organic layer thickness (OLT), and plant species cover. These geospatial datasets are the foundation for the journal article, "Evidence for non-uniform permafrost degradation after fire in boreal landscapes", published in the Journal of Geophysical Research - Earth Surface.
descript.purpose: Data were collected to quantify the belowground impacts of fire on permafrost in boreal landscapes.

spdom.descgeog: Interior Alaska, near Fairbanks and southeast along the Alaska Highway towards Canada

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

method.methdesc: At each site we described and measured the thickness of the active-, organic-, and mineral-soil layers to depths of about 30 - 40 cm with observations being spaced every 1 - 30 m along the transect depending on site heterogeneity. Soil landscapes were described based on ecological landscape classifications, and dominant soil texture was assigned using mapped surficial geology classes and site descriptions of soil horizons. Thaw depth measurements were made with a stainless steel permafrost probe with extensions up to 250 cm. Organic layer thickness measurements were made from soil plugs.

citeinfo.origin: Jorgenson, T., K. Yoshikawa, M. Kanevskiy, Y. Shur, V. Romanovsky, S. Marchenko, G. Grosse, J. Brown, and B. Jones
citeinfo.title: Reorganization of vegetation, hydrology and soil carbon after permafrost degradation across heterogeneous boreal landscapes

procstep.procdesc: Soils data were manually recorded in the field, and later transcribed digitally and stored.
